trans-unit.source: How to use Blob Storage from Xamarin (Preview) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Blob Storage from Xamarin (Preview) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: The Azure Storage Client Library for Xamarin preview enables developers to create iOS, Android, and Windows Store apps with their native user interfaces.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Storage Client Library for Xamarin preview enables developers to create iOS, Android, and Windows Store apps with their native user interfaces.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how to use Xamarin to create an Android application that uses Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how to use Xamarin to create an Android application that uses Azure Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: How to use Blob Storage from Xamarin (Preview)
trans-unit.target: How to use Blob Storage from Xamarin (Preview)

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: Xamarin enables developers to use a shared C# codebase to create iOS, Android, and Windows Store apps with their native user interfaces.
trans-unit.target: Xamarin enables developers to use a shared C# codebase to create iOS, Android, and Windows Store apps with their native user interfaces.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Storage Client Library for Xamarin is a preview library; note that it may change in the future.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Storage Client Library for Xamarin is a preview library; note that it may change in the future.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to use Azure Blob storage with a Xamarin Android application.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to use Azure Blob storage with a Xamarin Android application.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about Azure Storage before diving into the code, see [Next steps](#next-steps) at the end of this document.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about Azure Storage before diving into the code, see [Next steps](#next-steps) at the end of this document.

trans-unit.source: Generate a Shared Access Signature
trans-unit.target: Generate a Shared Access Signature

trans-unit.source: When developing with the Azure Storage Client Library for Xamarin, you cannot authenticate access to an Azure Storage account using your account access keys.
trans-unit.target: When developing with the Azure Storage Client Library for Xamarin, you cannot authenticate access to an Azure Storage account using your account access keys.

trans-unit.source: This is to prevent your account credentials from being distributed to users that may download your app.
trans-unit.target: This is to prevent your account credentials from being distributed to users that may download your app.

trans-unit.source: Instead, we encourage the use of shared access signatures (SAS), which won’t expose your account credentials.
trans-unit.target: Instead, we encourage the use of shared access signatures (SAS), which won’t expose your account credentials.

trans-unit.source: In this guide, we'll use Azure PowerShell to generate a SAS token.
trans-unit.target: In this guide, we'll use Azure PowerShell to generate a SAS token.

trans-unit.source: Then we'll create a Xamarin app that uses the generated SAS.
trans-unit.target: Then we'll create a Xamarin app that uses the generated SAS.

trans-unit.source: First, you’ll need to install Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: First, you’ll need to install Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Check out [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](../powershell-install-configure.md#Install) for instructions.
trans-unit.target: Check out [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](../powershell-install-configure.md#Install) for instructions.

trans-unit.source: Next, open Azure PowerShell and run the following commands.
trans-unit.target: Next, open Azure PowerShell and run the following commands.

trans-unit.source: Remember to replace `ACCOUNT_NAME` and `ACCOUNT_KEY== ` with your storage account credentials.
trans-unit.target: Remember to replace `ACCOUNT_NAME` and `ACCOUNT_KEY== ` with your storage account credentials.

trans-unit.source: Replace `CONTAINER_NAME` with a name of your choosing.
trans-unit.target: Replace `CONTAINER_NAME` with a name of your choosing.

trans-unit.source: The shared access signature URI for the new container should be similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: The shared access signature URI for the new container should be similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: The shared access signature that you created on the container will be valid for the next day.
trans-unit.target: The shared access signature that you created on the container will be valid for the next day.

trans-unit.source: The signature grants full permissions (*e.g.*, read, write, delete, and list) to blobs within the container.
trans-unit.target: The signature grants full permissions (*e.g.*, read, write, delete, and list) to blobs within the container.

trans-unit.source: For more information about shared access signatures, see the [SAS tutorial for .NET](storage-dotnet-shared-access-signature-part-2.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about shared access signatures, see the [SAS tutorial for .NET](storage-dotnet-shared-access-signature-part-2.md).

trans-unit.source: Create a new Xamarin Application
trans-unit.target: Create a new Xamarin Application

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial, we'll be creating our Xamarin application in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial, we'll be creating our Xamarin application in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Follow these steps to create the application:
trans-unit.target: Follow these steps to create the application:

trans-unit.source: Download and install [Visual Studio](https://www.visualstudio.com/).
trans-unit.target: Download and install [Visual Studio](https://www.visualstudio.com/).

trans-unit.source: Download and install [Xamarin](http://xamarin.com/platform).
trans-unit.target: Download and install [Xamarin](http://xamarin.com/platform).

trans-unit.source: Open Visual Studio, and select **File > New > Project > Android > Blank App(Android)**.
trans-unit.target: Open Visual Studio, and select **File > New > Project > Android > Blank App(Android)**.

trans-unit.source: Right-click your project in the Solution Explorer pane and select **Manage NuGet Packages**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click your project in the Solution Explorer pane and select **Manage NuGet Packages**.

trans-unit.source: Then search for **Azure Storage** and install **Azure Storage 4.4.0-preview**.
trans-unit.target: Then search for **Azure Storage** and install **Azure Storage 4.4.0-preview**.

trans-unit.source: You should now have an application that allows you to click a button and increment a counter.
trans-unit.target: You should now have an application that allows you to click a button and increment a counter.

trans-unit.source: Use the shared access signature to perform container operations
trans-unit.target: Use the shared access signature to perform container operations

trans-unit.source: Next, add code to perform a series of container operations using the SAS URI that you generated.
trans-unit.target: Next, add code to perform a series of container operations using the SAS URI that you generated.

trans-unit.source: First add the following **using** statements:
trans-unit.target: First add the following **using** statements:

trans-unit.source: Next, add a line for your SAS token.
trans-unit.target: Next, add a line for your SAS token.

trans-unit.source: Replace the `"SAS_URI"` string with the SAS URI that you generated in Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Replace the `"SAS_URI"` string with the SAS URI that you generated in Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Then add a line for a call to the `UseContainerSAS` method that we’ll create below.
trans-unit.target: Then add a line for a call to the `UseContainerSAS` method that we’ll create below.

trans-unit.source: Note that the **async** keyword has been added before the delegate.
trans-unit.target: Note that the **async** keyword has been added before the delegate.

trans-unit.source: Add a new method, `UseContainerSAS`, under the `OnCreate` method.
trans-unit.target: Add a new method, `UseContainerSAS`, under the `OnCreate` method.

trans-unit.source: Run the application
trans-unit.target: Run the application

trans-unit.source: You can now run this application in an emulator or Android device.
trans-unit.target: You can now run this application in an emulator or Android device.

trans-unit.source: Although this getting started focused on Android, you can use the `UseContainerSAS` method in your iOS or Windows Store applications as well.
trans-unit.target: Although this getting started focused on Android, you can use the `UseContainerSAS` method in your iOS or Windows Store applications as well.

trans-unit.source: Xamarin also allows developers to create Windows Phone apps; however, our library does not yet support this.
trans-unit.target: Xamarin also allows developers to create Windows Phone apps; however, our library does not yet support this.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you learned how to use Azure Blob storage and SAS with a Xamarin application.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you learned how to use Azure Blob storage and SAS with a Xamarin application.

trans-unit.source: As a further exercise, a similar pattern could be applied to generate a SAS token for an Azure table or queue.
trans-unit.target: As a further exercise, a similar pattern could be applied to generate a SAS token for an Azure table or queue.

trans-unit.target: Learn more about blobs, tables, and queues by checking out the following links:

trans-unit.target: [Introduction to Microsoft Azure Storage](storage-introduction.md)
